platea package¶

Submodules¶

platea.distributions module¶

Distributions¶

This mode includes functions and classes for working with probability distributions.

Notes

The docstring examples assume that distributions has been imported as dist::
>>> from platea import distributions as dist
class platea.distributions.Normal(mu: float = None, sigma: float = None)¶

Bases: object

Normal (Gaussian) distribution.

Notes

Numerical Recipes 3Ed 6.14.1

mu float

The mean of the Gaussian distribution.

sigma float

The standard deviation of the Gaussian distribution. (square root of the variance)

state_size int

The length of the state array of the rng used in the draw method

pdf(x, mu, sigma)¶

Evaluate the pdf of the distribution at x.

cdf(x, mu, sigma)¶

Evaluate the cdf of the distribution at x.

invdcdf(p, mu, sigma)¶

Evaluate the invcdf of the distribution at p.

draw(n, mu, sigma)¶

Sample random number(s).

set_state(seed)¶

Set the internal state of the rng.

get_state()¶

Get the current internal state of the rng.

Examples

>>> norm = dist.Normal(mu=0.0, sigma=1.0)
>>> pdf_value = norm.pdf(0.57)
>>> sample = norm.draw(n=1)
cdf(x: Union[float, numpy.ndarray], mu: float = None, sigma: float = None) → numpy.ndarray

Cummulative density function.

Parameters

  • x (float, ndarray[float], ndarray[float, float]]) – Real valued argument to the function. Can be a single value or an array. Can be one or two dimensional.

  • mu (float) – The mean of the Gaussian distribution. If None then uses the class attribute value.

  • sigma (float) – The standard deviation of the Gaussian distribution. (square root of the variance). If None then uses the class attribute value.

Returns

function value

Return type

ndarray

draw(n: int = 1, mu: float = None, sigma: float = None) → numpy.ndarray

Draw random numbers valued [0.0, 1.0].

Parameters

  • n (int, tuple(int, int)) – The number of samples to draw. Can be one or two dimensional.

  • mu (float) – The mean of the Gaussian distribution. If None then uses the class attribute value.

  • sigma (float) – The standard deviation of the Gaussian distribution. (square root of the variance). If None then uses the class attribute value.

Returns

samples from the distribution

Return type

ndarray[float]

get_state() → numpy.ndarray

Get the internal state of the rng.

Parameters

None –

Returns

the current internal state of the RNG

Return type

ndarray[int]

invcdf(p: Union[float, numpy.ndarray], mu: float = None, sigma: float = None) → numpy.ndarray¶

Inverse cummulative density function.

Parameters

  • p (float, ndarray[float], ndarray[float, float]]) – Real valued argument to the function. Can be a single value or an array. Can be one or two dimensional. Should be a probability [0.0, 1.0]

  • mu (float) – The mean of the Gaussian distribution. If None then uses the class attribute value.

  • sigma (float) – The standard deviation of the Gaussian distribution. (square root of the variance). If None then uses the class attribute value.

Returns

function value

Return type

ndarray

pdf(x: Union[float, numpy.ndarray], mu: float = None, sigma: float = None) → numpy.ndarray

Probability density function.

Parameters

  • x (float, ndarray[float], ndarray[float, float]]) – Real valued argument to the function. Can be a single value or an array. Can be one or two dimensional.

  • mu (float) – The mean of the Gaussian distribution. If None then uses the class attribute value.

  • sigma (float) – The standard deviation of the Gaussian distribution. (square root of the variance). If None then uses the class attribute value.

Returns

function value

Return type

ndarray

set_state(seed: Union[int, numpy.ndarray]) → None

Set the state of the rng.

Parameters

seed (int, ndarray[int]) – The seed for the rng. See the docs for the platea default rng: help(pla.random_number_generators.ran)

Returns

Return type

None

platea.random_number_generators module¶

Random Number Generators¶

This module contains random number generators (RNGs). These RNGs are operating system (OS) agnostic.

Notes

The docstring examples assume that random_number_generators has been imported as rng::
>>> from platea import random_number_generators as rng
platea.random_number_generators.Ran¶

alias of platea.random_number_generators.Ran2

class platea.random_number_generators.Ran0(seed: Union[int, numpy.ndarray] = -99999999999)¶

Bases: object

Random number generator (RNG).

Notes

Numerical Recipes in Fortran77 Ch7.1 <ran0> Numerical Recipes in C 2Ed Ch7.1 <ran0>

state_size int

The length of the state array of the rng

set_state(seed)¶

Set the internal state of the rng.

get_state()¶

Get the current internal state of the rng.

draw(n)¶

Sample random number(s).

Examples

>>> random_number_generator = rng.Ran0()
>>> state = random_number_generator.get_state()
>>> random_number_generator.set_state(seed=state)
>>> random_number = random_number_generator.draw(n=1)
draw(n: Union[int, Tuple[int, int]] = 1) → numpy.ndarray

Draw random numbers valued [0.0, 1.0].

Parameters

n (int, tuple(int, int)) – The number of samples to draw. Can be one or two dimensional.

Returns

samples from a uniform distribution [0.0, 1.0]

Return type

ndarray[float]

get_state() → numpy.ndarray

Get the internal state of the rng.

Parameters

None –

Returns

the current internal state of the RNG

Return type

ndarray[int]

set_state(seed: Union[int, numpy.ndarray]) → None

Set the state of the rng.

Parameters

seed (int, ndarray[int]) – If an integer valued [-99999999999, 0], the RNG will be rest using that seed. Any other value will set the state of the RNG. For example, you could set the state of RNG one to the state of RNG two rather than resetting RNG one with a new seed.

Returns

Return type

None

Set the state of the rng.

platea.special_functions module¶

Special Functions¶

Special functions commonly used in numerical calculations.

Notes

The docstring examples assume that special_functions has been imported as sf::
>>> from platea import special_functions as sf

platea.special_functions.gammap(a: Union[float, numpy.ndarray], x: Union[float, numpy.ndarray]) → numpy.ndarray¶

Lower incomplete gamma function. CDF of the gamma distribution.

Notes

NIST: https://dlmf.nist.gov/8.2#E4 Numerical Recipes 3Ed 6.2

Parameters

  • a (float, ndarray[float], ndarray[float, float]) – Parametertizes the gamma distribution. Must be > 0.0 Can be a single value or an array. Can be one or two dimensional.

  • x (float, ndarray[float], ndarray[float, float]) – Probability expressed as a value 0.0 to 1.0. Must be >= 0.0 Can be a single value or an array. Can be one or two dimensional.

Returns

function value

Return type

ndarray

platea.special_functions.gammaq(a: Union[float, numpy.ndarray], x: Union[float, numpy.ndarray]) → numpy.ndarray¶

Notes

Parameters

  • a (float, ndarray[float], ndarray[float, float]) – Parametertizes the gamma distribution. Must be > 0.0 Can be a single value or an array. Can be one or two dimensional.

  • x (float, ndarray[float], ndarray[float, float]) – Non-negative argument. Must be >= 0.0 Can be a single value or an array. Can be one or two dimensional.

Returns

platea.utilities module¶

Utilities¶

Assorted utilities for the Platea package.

class platea.utilities.Timer¶

Bases: object

Timer.

A convenient class for timing things.

None¶
None()

Examples

>>> with pla.utilities.Timer()
>>>     do someting
platea.utilities.deprecated(func)¶

A decorator used to mark functions that are deprecated with a warning.

Examples

>>> @deprecated
>>> def foo():
>>>     do something

Module contents¶

Platea¶

A package for simple numerical methods.

How to use the documentation¶

The docstring examples assume that platea has been imported as pla::
>>> import platea as pla
Code snippets are indicated by three greater-than signs::
>>> x = 42
>>> x = x + 1
Use the built-in help function to view a function’s docstring::
>>> help(pla)
or dir::
>>> dir(pla)
You can check the annotations of a function to see type hints::
>>> pla.spcl_fnc.gamma.__annotations__

By conventions, look to modeule docstrings for source references and definitions of important terms / acronyms.

>>> help(pla.rng)

Available subpackages¶

rng

random number generators

dist

tools for working with statistical distribution

spcl_fnc

special mathematical functions like the error function
